Renown & Rank

Among the Garou, power is not measured solely by survival or strength. It is measured by Renown—the recognition of deeds—and Rank, the status earned through action, honor, and wisdom.

A Garou’s place in society is shaped less by age or bloodline than by what they have proven before witnesses, spirits, and their peers.

What Is Renown?

Renown is the spiritual and social weight of a Garou’s actions.

It reflects how the Garou is perceived by:

  • Other Garou

  • Spirits and totems

  • The sept as a whole

Renown is earned through deeds that uphold Garou values and lost through failure, dishonor, or neglect of duty.

The Three Paths of Renown

Renown is traditionally recognized in three forms:

Glory

Glory is earned through courage, victory, and visible acts of strength. It is the renown of warriors, champions, and those who face impossible odds without retreat.

Honor

Honor reflects adherence to the Litany, loyalty to one’s pack and sept, and restraint in the use of power. It is earned by those who choose duty over convenience.

Wisdom

Wisdom is earned through insight, foresight, and spiritual understanding. It reflects patience, teaching, and the ability to see consequences beyond the present moment.

No Garou excels equally in all three.

What Is Rank?

Rank is the formal recognition of a Garou’s accumulated Renown.

It determines:

  • Authority within a sept

  • Eligibility to perform certain rites

  • Leadership roles

  • Expectations of responsibility

Rank is not automatic. It must be earned, acknowledged, and maintained.

Advancement Through Deed

Rising in Rank requires more than raw accomplishment.

A Garou must:

  • Demonstrate balanced Renown

  • Be recognized by peers and elders

  • Earn spiritual acknowledgment

  • Accept greater responsibility

Some Garou refuse Rank, fearing the obligations it brings. Others pursue it obsessively, mistaking authority for worth.

Social Consequences of Rank

Rank shapes every interaction.

Higher-ranked Garou are expected to:

  • Lead in times of crisis

  • Mediate disputes

  • Uphold tradition

  • Accept challenges

Lower-ranked Garou are expected to:

  • Learn

  • Serve

  • Obey reasonable commands

  • Prove themselves

These expectations are enforced socially long before they are enforced violently.

Loss of Renown

Renown is fragile.

Violating the Litany, abandoning a sept, betraying spirits, or repeatedly succumbing to Frenzy can erode a Garou’s standing. A respected Garou can fall quickly—and recovery is never guaranteed.

Some falls are permanent.

Spirits and Judgment

Spirits observe Renown closely.

A Garou may earn respect among their people and still be scorned by the Umbra. Likewise, a Garou ignored by sept politics may be favored by powerful spirits.

True power lies where both recognize worth.

Why Renown and Rank Matter

Renown and Rank define who the Garou trust, who they follow, and who they fear.

They are the glue that holds Garou society together—and the fault lines along which it breaks.

A Garou without Renown is invisible.
A Garou without restraint is dangerous.
A Garou with Rank must bear the weight of both.
